Posted: Thursday, August 6, 2015 3:13 pm

Seven Lakes beach remains closed Friday 0 comments

The beach at Seven Lakes State Park off of Fish Lake Road in Holly remains closed today, Friday, Aug. 7. According to park staff, the beach was closed to swimmers on Thursday, Aug. 6 while the Oakland County Health Department conducted water quality testing as a result of goose droppings. The health department had not, as of noon Friday, revealed those results or indicated to park staff that the beach could re-open.

<meta content="PARIS (KFSM) -- The city of Paris was put under a mandatory boil order Wednesday (August 5) following a main water line break.

Dozens of residents, mainly in higher elevations, were without water and all others were experiencing very low water pressure, according to city officials.

A service line broke around 4 p.m. Wednesday on South I Street. Crews were able to get the line repaired quickly, but later that afternoon a main water line broke affecting all Paris residents. City workers said when they first noticed a break in the line it was six-inches wide, but the line broke further into a five-foot hole." property="og:description"/>

<h4 class="title">City Of Paris Under Mandatory Boil Order Following Main Water Line Break</h4>
</div>
<div class="modal-body">
<img alt="" class="attachment-gallery-cover size-gallery-cover wp-post-image" height="513" sizes="(max-width: 770px) 100vw, 770px" src="http://localtvkfsm.files.wordpress.com/2015/08/boil-order.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=770" srcset="http://localtvkfsm.files.wordpress.com/2015/08/boil-order.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=770 770w, http://localtvkfsm.files.wordpress.com/2015/08/boil-order.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=1540 1540w, http://localtvkfsm.files.wordpress.com/2015/08/boil-order.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=150 150w, http://localtvkfsm.files.wordpress.com/2015/08/boil-order.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=300 300w, http://localtvkfsm.files.wordpress.com/2015/08/boil-order.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=1024 1024w" width="770"/> <div class="lightbox-caption"></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>PARIS (KFSM) — The city of Paris was put under a mandatory boil order Wednesday (August 5) following a main water line break.</p>
<p>Dozens of residents, mainly in higher elevations, were without water and all others were experiencing very low water pressure, according to city officials.</p>
<p>A service line broke around 4 p.m. Wednesday on South I Street. Crews were able to get the line repaired quickly, but later that afternoon a main water line broke affecting all Paris residents. City workers said when they first noticed a break in the line it was six-inches wide, but the line broke further into a five-foot hole.</p>
<p>The line has been fixed, but problems with water pressure will continue until at least Friday, according to city officials. The mandatory boil order will be in place until the city gets passing water samples for two consecutive days.</p>
<p>Notice will be posted on the <a href="https://www.facebook.com/cityofparis.arkansas?fref=nf" target="_blank">City of Paris Facebook page</a> as soon as the order is lifted.</p>
</div>

Scituate beach closed due to bacteria

Thursday
Aug 6, 2015 at 1:33 AM Aug 6, 2015 at 1:47 AM

Patriot Ledger staff

SCITUATE – Swimming could be prohibited at Lighthouse Beach for at least the next week due to high amounts of bacteria in the water.

Town officials announced the closure Wednesday following routine tests for enterococci, which are conducted each Tuesday at six of the town’s beaches from June until Labor Day.

The test showed 1,439 enterococci colonies per 100 milliliters of water. The state Department of Public Health has deemed 104 colonies per 100 milliliters the safe maximum. The last test, on July 27, showed less than 10 colonies per 100 milliliters of water at Lighthouse Beach.

The town was expected to retest water on Wednesday, and the results were to be released today.

The last time Lighthouse Beach showed high levels of enterococci, on July 21, the bacteria was back to healthy levels the following day.

<div class="asset-content subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<p>The city has issued a precautionary water boil order for some customers following water main breaks Wednesday.</p><p>There were six breaks, all of which City of Bloomington Utilities crews had fixed by evening.</p><p>The breaks occurred in the:</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><p>• 1700 block of East 10th Street.</p><p>• 3500 block of East Morningside Drive.</p><p>• 2800 block of North Walnut Street.</p><p>• 2600 block of North Kinser Pike.</p><p>• 400 block of East Ninth Street.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"><div class="tncms-block" id="tncms-block-602072"><div id="schurz-sciInStoryMixpo" style="display: none; height: 0px;" title="Advertisement">
<script type="text/javascript">
	   googletag.cmd.push(function(){googletag.display('schurz-sciInStoryMixpo')}); 
    </script>
</div></div></div><p>• 900 block of South Hawthorne Drive.</p><p>Eleven areas fall under the precautionary boil order: North Lane Condominiums, Amaryllis Condominiums, and customers on West Hoosier Court Avenue, West Parrish Road, West Skyline Drive, North Skyline Drive, West Dogwood Lane, West Clover Terrace, North Cascade Drive, North Maxine Road and North Kinser Pike between West Brookdale Drive and West Briar Cliff Drive are advised to boil drinking water for five minutes prior to consumption until further notice and to flush their water systems by running cold water through all fixtures until it runs clear.</p><p>Utilities officials were confident the breaks were related to a change in conditions after the department emptied its largest water storage tank in the central zone of the city's water distribution system. That tank is located at 17th Street and the Ind. 45/46 Bypass, department spokesman Jon Callahan said, and was emptied for a scheduled, routine painting.</p><p>All six streets had opened to traffic by 6 p.m. Wednesday.</p><p>Bloomington High School North principal Jeffry Henderson sent a message to the school's main email subscription list early Wednesday morning with a simple detour for those approaching the high school, which is off North Kinser Pike. Should that section of the road be closed in the future, drivers can take a left onto West Skyline Drive, a right onto North Cascade Drive, another right onto North Skyline Drive and then turn left back onto North Kinser Pike.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom"></div>
</div>

        jQuery(document).ready(function($){
            var bThrottle = false;
            var $region = $('#tncms-region-asset_side_sticky');

            if (
                $region.is(':empty') === false &&
                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&
                window.innerWidth >= 992
            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="asset_side_sticky-placeholder"></div>');
                $region.before($tempRegion);
                $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );

                $(window).on('scroll mousewheel', function(){
                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 30;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 30) {
                                $region.css('top', null);
                                $region.removeClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else if (
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#infinite-container') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#site-footer-container')
                            ) {
                                $region.removeClass('affix')
                                $region.addClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else {
                                $region.css('top', 30);
                                $region.addClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');
                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }
                });

                $(window).on('resize', function(){
                    $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );
                });
            }
        });
    </script>
</div>
</div></div>

	function replaceCardLead() {
		var allLeads = document.getElementsByClassName("card-lead");
		for (var i = 0; i < allLeads.length; i++) {
			var oldLead = document.getElementsByClassName("card-lead")[i];
			var newLead = oldLead.innerHTML.replace(/(<p[^>]+?>|<p>|<\/p>)/img, " ");
			document.getElementsByClassName("card-lead")[i].innerHTML = newLead;
		}
	}


	document.onkeyup = KeyCheck;
	function KeyCheck(e) {
		var KeyID = (window.event) ? event.keyCode : e.keyCode;
		switch(KeyID) {
		case 27:
			// Escape key
			if (document.getElementById('postit')) {
				document.getElementById('postit').style.visibility = 'hidden';
				document.getElementById('postit').style.display = 'none';
			}

			if (document.getElementById('headerAdPW')) {

				document.getElementById('wrapperAdPW').style.visibility = 'hidden';
				document.getElementById('wrapperAdPW').style.display = 'none';
				document.body.style.marginTop = '0px';
			}
			break;
		}
	}

Lexington Boil Water Order Lifted

By TWC News Staff  |  August 5, 2015 @3:45 PM
SHARE

LEXINGTON, N.C. -  Officials with Lexington Utilities have lifted the boil water order.

They say lab results on samples taken Tuesday show the water is clear for consumption. 

City officials didn't want people cooking with or drinking water after the largest water main break in the city's history happened Monday.

Crews had the break repaired yesterday, but wanted to be sure the water was free of any contaminants before letting people get back to business as usual. 

If you are still having major problems with your water, call the city at 336-248-3930.

<div class="card-body">

<h3 class="">
<a href="/news/puppet-show-teaches-how-to-deal-with-bullies/article_3bdf1e32-d652-11e7-9282-bb7aaea64bf4.html">
        

        
        Puppet show teaches how to deal with bullies</a></h3>
</div>
<div class="card-lead">
<p>PLATTSBURGH — Seton Academy fifth-grade students in Karen Reynolds and Kathleen Toner’s fifth-grade classes recently participated in an anti-bullying workshop presented by puppeteer educators Sarah Vogelsang-Card and Deb Lyons with Puppets in Education. </p>

<div class="asset-content subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<p>JAY — As a result of a water main break, Town of Jay water users from the four-corner intersection of routes 9 and 86 and extending down to the Rosio residence on Route 9 are under a boil-water order.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><p>It affects only these residents.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"><div class="tncms-block visible-xs" id="tncms-block-1108091">
<!-- Mobile Rectangle ATF 300x250 article -->
<div class="visible-xs visible-sm" id="mobileRectangle_atf" style="width:100%;text-align:center">
<script type="text/javascript">
AdBridg.cmd.push(function() { AdBridg.display('mobileRectangle_atf'); });
</script>
</div>
<div class="clear" style="padding-bottom:10px"></div>
</div></div>
<p>The Town of Jay has bottled water available at the Community Center at 11 School Lane between 7 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. for those affected by the boil-water order.</p><p>Call Town of Jay Supervisor Archie Depo at 647-2204 x103 or Town of Jay DPW Director Robbie Lincoln at 647-2204, Ext. 125, with any questions.</p><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom"></div>
</div>

Lexington Water Main Break Fixed

By Meg Smith  |  August 4, 2015 @8:27 PM
SHARE

LEXINGTON, N.C.- A boil advisory remains in effect in Lexington after the largest water main break in the city's history.   

It happened early Monday morning off Hillside Drive, and forced several businesses—including the BBQ Center –to close.

"We're making progress,” said owner Cecil Conrad. “We got the guidelines from the health department to find out what we can and can't do. Based on that, we have limited drink service. Bottled water and canned soda. No iced tea. We're able to operate, using bagged ice."

Workers have repaired the break that caused several businesses to close, and spent the day Tuesday fixing the street at the site of the mess.

"The tanks are recovered and citizens should already be experiencing an increase in water,” said public services manager Roger Jones.

Workers also tested hydrants throughout the city to make sure air and dirty water are out of the lines.

City and state officials continued to collect samples throughout the day Tuesday, and hope to have that boil order lifted by Wednesday.

"That is just a precautionary measure,” Jones said. “Citizens are OK to use it for bathing purposes and in toilets. If they want to consume it for themselves or their pets they need to vigorously boil it for a minute. It has been a major inconvenience for our customers and we apologize. We do commend them because most have had a really good spirit about it."

Sentiment echoed by Conrad, whose livelihood depends on the city's water.

"City employees did an outstanding job,” Conrad said. “The water lines were fixed a couple hours ahead of time. We're just waiting on the state to release everything. Everyone is working as hard as they can, and we just have to be patient."

Customers still having major problems with their water are asked to call the city at (336) 248-3930.

<div class="asset-content subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<p>GOSHEN — Residents who live in the 1100, 1200 or 1300 blocks of Division Street and the 500 block of North Riverside Blvd. are under a water boiling advisory beginning Wednesday.</p><p>A scheduled water main shut down for installation of a new fire hydrant will be performed Wednesday starting at 8 a.m. and lasting until 4 p.m.</p>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset, atf","fold":"above","include_domain":"cnhi\/goshennews","size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/goshennews.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news\/local_news"}' style="display:none;"></div>
<div data-refreshable="true" data-region="fixed-big-ad-top-asset">
</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><p>City water within the affected area should not be consumed without first following prescribed boiling procedures. The water remains safe for bathing, laundry, and restroom facilities, according to city staff. Cleaning dishes with a dishwasher is acceptable if it has a sanitizing cycle. Hand washed dishes should be rinse with boiled or bottled water.</p><p>According to water department staff, the Indiana Department of Environmental Management requires the water utility to issue a boil water order for the affected area.</p>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset, stf","fold":"span","include_domain":"cnhi\/goshennews","size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/goshennews.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news\/local_news"}' style="display:none;"></div>
<div data-refreshable="true" data-region="fixed-big-ad-middle-asset">
</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"><div class="tncms-block visible-xs" id="tncms-block-1150602">

<div class="clear" style="padding-bottom:10px"></div>
</div></div><p>After the fire hydrant is installed, water samples will be taken and analyzed for the presence of bacteria. If two consecutive tests pass, the boil order will be lifted.</p><p>For further information or to report specific service concerns, call Mindy Kyle at the Goshen Water Department at 534-5306.</p>

2 Mid-Michigan beaches closed for bacteria levels, health advisory issued for river

Posted: Updated:
By Brianna Owczarzak, Digital producer
Email
Connect
brianna.owczarzak@wnem.com
Follow @briannaowczar
BAY COUNTY, MI (WNEM) -

Two beaches in Mid-Michigan are closed for full body contact recreational activities.

The samples from Wenona Beach and South Linwood Beach in Bay County have exceeded the state’s water quality standard, the Bay County Health Department said.

The beaches will open when bacteria levels comply with the state’s water standards.

Water samples from the Kawkawlin River also exceeded the state’s water standards for full body contact recreational activities, the department said.

A public health advisory has been issued for the river. The advisory will be lifted when water levels comply with the state’s standards.

The samples were collected on Aug. 3.

A public health advisory has been issued for the river. The advisory will be lifted when water levels comply with the state’s standards.

The samples were collected on Aug. 3.

<div class="MainColumn ContentDefault " id="StoryHeader">
<div class="storyHead">
<h1 class="headline headline-2729964">A boil-water alert shows a lack of communication between the Sewerage & Water Board and New Orleans residents </h1>
</div>
</div> <!-- end StoryHeader -->
<div class="MainColumn ContentDefault " id="StoryLayout">
<div class="page1" id="storyBody">
<p>Cedric Grant, director of the Sewerage & Water Board of New Orleans (S&WB), held a press conference last week to address the city's latest boil-water alert, which was issued at 10 a.m. on July 24. The alert came a full seven hours after power went out at the Carrollton water plant, potentially allowing for contamination of the East Bank water supply. Grant promised to do better next time and said the city is midway through upgrades at the Carrollton plant. What Grant didn't address is his agency's failure to inform citizens in a timely way.</p>
<p>  The boil-water order was issued on a Friday morning (after residents had their coffee, brushed their teeth, showered, etc.) and continued overnight. There was a run on bottled water at local stores; restaurants and bars had to adjust at their own expense. Not a word came from the city for the rest of the day. The next morning, 24 hours later, the city sent an email saying water samples were still being tested. Then, more silence.</p>
<p>  Brad Howard, a spokesman for Mayor Mitch Landrieu, disputed that account, saying, "Sewerage & Water Board and the City utilized multiple platforms to communicate with the public throughout this incident, including a major press conference, three press releases (one on Friday and two on Saturday), stakeholder outreach, active engagement on social media (via @NOLAReady), NOLA-311, NOLA Ready text alerts and S&WB's 24-hour hotline 52-WATER (529-2837)."</p>
<blockquote class="pull">
<font color="#800517" size="“+1”"><b>The simple step of having someone around on the weekend to keep the public informed would be a good start.</b></font>
</blockquote>
<p>  Hoping to address frantic inquiries from readers, <i>Gambit</i> spent much of Saturday trying to reach someone — anyone — who could provide answers. The S&WB hotline went unanswered. The city's 311 information line offered a recording that said the office was closed. The city's website had no information. The emergency preparedness Twitter account for the city (@NOLAReady) tweeted that the boil-water order was still in effect at 8:43 a.m. It didn't address the issue again for more than eight hours, when the order was lifted. That's <i>not</i> communication.</p>
<p>  Grant earns $210,000 per year — $60,000 more than the mayor. In June, Jaquetta White of <i>The New Orleans Advocate</i> reported that Grant also spent $60,000 redecorating his office, including a 70-inch, $30,666 "SMART board" (essentially a high-tech whiteboard). Grant explained the purchases thus: "I think it was a very wise investment in relation to our ability to manage better and bring ourselves into the modern age in relation to how we need to manage and communicate with people." Too bad Grant didn't use that pricey equipment to communicate on July 24-25. Tweeting and emailing cost nothing.</p>
<p>  By now, New Orleanians are accustomed to boil-water orders. They know New Orleans' water system is old and prone to failure. Less understandable is the city's failure to communicate with citizens.</p>
<p>  "As with any major incident, our teams will work together to fully review all protocols and actions taken to make necessary improvements, particularly in how quickly, frequently and comprehensively we communicate with the public," Grant said in a statement to <i>Gambit</i>. "Public safety is and will remain our top priority."</p>
<p>  The simple step of having someone around on the weekend to keep the public informed would be a good start.</p>
</div>
</div> <!-- end StoryLayout -->

<script type="text/javascript">
        var componentId = "Comments";

        function updateCommentTotals (showing,total){
          if (showing) {
            jQuery(".commentsShowingUpdate").each(function(){jQuery(this).html(showing)});
          }
          if (total==0) total="0";
          if (total){
            jQuery(".commentsTotalUpdate").each(function(){jQuery(this).html(total)});
          }
        }

        

        
        function getMoreComments (e) {
          if (e) e.preventDefault();
          if (jQuery(this).attr("id") == "showAllComments" || jQuery(this).attr("id") == "showMoreComments"){
            jQuery(this).parent().html('<div class="commentSpinner"> </div>');
          } else if (jQuery(this).attr("id") == "sortSelect"){
            jQuery("#Comments .sortSpinner").show();
          }

          var url = "/gambit/failure-to-communicate/Content?oid=2729964";
          var myStart = jQuery(this).attr("id") == "sortSelect" ? "1" : jQuery(this).attr("rel");
          var showAllComments = jQuery(this).attr("id") == "showAllComments" ? "yes" : "no";
          if (!myStart) var myStart = "1";
          var mySort = jQuery("#sortSelect").val() || "asc";
          var params = {
            sort: mySort,
            ajaxComponent: componentId,
            startIndex: myStart,
            showAll: showAllComments
          };
          jQuery.ajax({
              url: url,
              data: (params),
              success: function (data) {
                  jQuery("#"+componentId+"_PaginationBottom").remove();
                  jQuery("#"+componentId+"_commentContent .brandNewComment").remove();
                  jQuery("#Comments .sortSpinner").hide();
                  if (myStart == "1") jQuery("#"+componentId+"_commentContent").html(data);
                  else jQuery("#"+componentId+"_commentContent").append(data);
              }
          });
        };

        function removeEdit(oid){
          if (oid){
            var cont = jQuery("#Comments-comment-"+oid).closest(".brandNewComment");
            cont.find(".newCommentOptions").fadeOut("fast", function(){
              jQuery(this).remove();
            });
          }
        }

        function getComment(oid, commentLimit){
          var url = "/gambit/failure-to-communicate/Content?oid=2729964";
          var limitMsg = commentLimit?"<div class=\"comment limitMsg\">\r\n\r\n      \r\n      \r\n        Note: Since you've already made  live comments to day(s)ay, this and any additional comments in this timeframe will be reviewed by our staff before being made live.  Thank you for your contribution!\r\n          \r\n    <\/div>":'';
          if (oid){
            var params = {
              ajaxComponent: componentId,
              commentOid: oid
            };
            jQuery.ajax({
                url: url,
                data: (params),
                success: function (data) {
                  if (!jQuery.trim(jQuery("#"+componentId+"_commentContent").html())){
                    jQuery("#"+componentId+"_commentContent").append(limitMsg+data).find(".brandNewComment").fadeIn("fast");
                  } else {
                    jQuery("#"+componentId+"_commentContent").children("div.comment, div.brandNewComment, div.limitMsg").filter(":last").after(limitMsg+data).parent().find(".brandNewComment").fadeIn("fast");
                  }
                  var t=setTimeout(function(){removeEdit(oid)},300000);
                  var myTotal = parseInt(jQuery("#comments_total").text(), 10);
                  myTotal++;
                  updateCommentTotals(false,myTotal);
                }
            });
          }
        }

        function doLikeComment(e){
          e.preventDefault();
          if (!this.clicked){
            var oid = jQuery(this).attr("data-commentOid");
            jQuery("#Comments #"+oid+"_likeLinks a").addClass("dimmed").css("opacity","0.4").each(function(){this.clicked = true;});

            var myCurrentLikes = jQuery("#"+oid+"_rating_likes").html() || 0;
            var myCurrentDislikes = jQuery("#"+oid+"_rating_dislikes").html() || 0;

            var thisRating = jQuery(this).attr("rel");
            if (thisRating == "Like"){
              myCurrentLikes = parseFloat(myCurrentLikes)+1;
            } else {
              myCurrentDislikes = parseFloat(myCurrentDislikes)+1;
            }
            var myNewLine = '<span id="'+oid+'_rating_likes">' + myCurrentLikes + '</span> like';
            if (myCurrentLikes != 1) {
              myNewLine += 's';
            }
            myNewLine += ', ' + '<span id="'+oid+'_rating_dislikes">' + myCurrentDislikes + '</span> dislike';
            if (myCurrentDislikes != 1) {
              myNewLine += "s";
            }

            jQuery("#"+oid+"_rating_sub").html(myNewLine);
            jQuery("#"+oid+"_rating_sub").show();

            var params = {
              oid: oid,
              rating: thisRating
            };
            jQuery.ajax({
                url: "/gyrobase/Tools/AjaxLike",
                type: "POST",
                data: (params),
                success: function (data) {
                  jQuery("#"+oid+"_rating_sub").html(data);
                  if (thisRating == "Like"){
                    jQuery("#Comments #"+oid+"_likeLinks a.dislike").removeClass("dimmed").css("opacity","1").each(function(){this.clicked = false;});
                  } else {
                    jQuery("#Comments #"+oid+"_likeLinks a.like").removeClass("dimmed").css("opacity","1").each(function(){this.clicked = false;});
                  }
                }
            });
          }
        }

        function reportComment(e){
          e.preventDefault();
          e.stopPropagation();
          var oid = jQuery(this).attr("rel");
          var elem = jQuery("#"+oid+"_report");
          elem.click(function(e){e.stopPropagation();})
          if (!elem.is(":visible")){
            jQuery("#Comments .reportCommentContainer").hide();
            if (elem.is(":empty")){
              var params = {
                oid: oid,
                ajaxComponent: "ReportComment"
              };
              jQuery.ajax({
                  url: "/gyrobase/Tools/ReportComment",
                  data: (params),
                  success: function (data) {
                    elem.html(data);
                    elem.fadeIn("fast");
                  }
              });
            } else {
              elem.fadeIn("fast");
            }
          }
          // attach close event handler to the html
          jQuery("html").one("click", function(){
            jQuery("#Comments .reportCommentContainer:visible").hide();
          });
        }

        function closeReport(obj){
          jQuery(obj).closest(".reportCommentContainer").fadeOut("fast");
        }

        function submitReport(e){
          var params = jQuery(e).closest("form").serialize()+"&ajaxComponent=ReportComment";
          jQuery.ajax({
              url: "/gyrobase/Tools/ReportComment",
              type: "POST",
              data: (params),
              success: function (data) {
                jQuery(e).closest(".reportCommentContainer").html(data);
              }
          });
        }

        (function($) {
          var subscribed=false;

          function showFollowPanel(e){
            e.preventDefault();
            myPanel = $(this).parent().next(".togglePanel");
            myPanel.fadeIn("fast");
          }

          function doSubscribe(obj){
            var myPanel = obj.parent().next(".togglePanel");
            myPanel.fadeIn("fast");
            if (!subscribed){
              var myLink = obj.parent();
              var myLoader = myPanel.children(".loading");
              var myUpdater = myPanel.children(".ajaxUpdater");
              var params = {
                object: myPanel.attr("data-toolsoid"),
                macro: myPanel.attr("data-toolsajaxmacro"),
                url: window.location
              };

              $.ajax({
                url: "/gyrobase/Macros/ToolsAjax",
                data: (params),
                type: "POST",
                dataType: "html",
                success: function (data) {
                  subscribed = true;
                  if (myUpdater){
                    myUpdater.html(data);
                    myLoader.fadeOut("fast", function(){
                      myUpdater.fadeIn("fast", function(){
                        setTimeout(function(){
                          myPanel.fadeOut("fast");
                        }, 3000);
                      });
                    });
                  } else {
                    myPanel.fadeOut("fast");
                  }
                }
              });
            }
          }

          function activateSubscribe(e){
            e.preventDefault();
            var myObj = $(this);
            var isAuthenticated = Foundation.SessionManager.sharedSessionManager().isAuthenticated();
            if (!isAuthenticated){
              new Foundation.Login.Dialog({
                  "feelingShy": false,
                  "callback": function(){doSubscribe(myObj);}
              });
              return false;
            } else {
              // Proceed
              doSubscribe(myObj);
            }
          }

          function deleteComment(e){
            e.preventDefault();
            var thisComment = $(this);
            var params = {
              macro: "deleteComment",
              comment: thisComment.attr("data-comment")
            };
            $.ajax({
              url: "/gyrobase/Macros/ToolsAjax",
              data: (params),
              type: "POST",
              dataType: "html",
              success: function (data) {
                thisComment.closest(".brandNewComment").fadeOut("fast", function(){
                  $(this).remove();
                  var myTotal = parseInt(jQuery("#comments_total").text(), 10);
                  myTotal--;
                  updateCommentTotals(false,myTotal);
                });
              }
            });
          }

          function editComment(e){
            e.preventDefault();
            var thisComment = $(this);
            var commentCont = thisComment.closest(".brandNewComment").find(".description");
            var commentTemp = thisComment.closest(".brandNewComment").find(".commentTemp");
            var commentText = commentTemp.html();
            var toolbar = thisComment.closest(".brandNewComment").find(".commentToolbar");
            commentCont.next(".commentEditCont").remove();
            commentCont.after('<div class="commentEditCont clearfix" style="display:none;"><div class="editErrorDisplay" style="display:none"><ol></ol></div><textarea class="expandableBox">'+commentText+'</textarea><a href="#" class="cancelEditLink">Cancel</a> <a href="#" class="doneEditLink" data-comment="'+thisComment.attr("data-comment")+'">SAVE</a></div>');
            toolbar.fadeOut("fast");
            commentCont.fadeOut("fast", function(){
              commentCont.next(".commentEditCont").fadeIn("fast", function(){
                $(".brandNewComment textarea.expandableBox").autoBoxResize();
                $(".brandNewComment textarea.expandableBox").focus();
              });
            });
          }

          function editCommentSave(e){
            e.preventDefault();
            var thisComment = $(this);
            var editCont = thisComment.closest(".commentEditCont");
            var commentTemp = thisComment.closest(".brandNewComment").find(".commentTemp");
            var newText = thisComment.prevAll("textarea").val();
            var toolbar = thisComment.closest(".brandNewComment").find(".commentToolbar");

            var params = {
              macro: "editComment",
              comment: thisComment.attr("data-comment"),
              commentText: newText
            };
            $.ajax({
              url: "/gyrobase/Macros/ToolsAjax",
              data: (params),
              type: "POST",
              success: function (data) {
                if (data.error){
                  $(".editErrorDisplay").html("<ol><li>"+data.error+"</li></ol>").fadeIn("fast");
                } else if (data.result){
                  editCont.fadeOut("fast", function(){
                    $(".editErrorDisplay").hide().html("<ol></ol>");
                    editCont.prev(".description").html($.trim(data.result));
                    commentTemp.html(newText);
                    editCont.prev(".description").fadeIn("fast");
                    toolbar.fadeIn("fast");
                  });
                }
              }
            });
          }

          function editCommentCancel(e){
            e.preventDefault();
            var editCont = $(this).closest(".commentEditCont");
            var toolbar = $(this).closest(".brandNewComment").find(".commentToolbar");
            editCont.fadeOut("fast", function(){
              $(".editErrorDisplay").hide().html("<ol></ol>");
              editCont.prev(".description").fadeIn("fast");
              toolbar.fadeIn("fast");
              editCont.remove();
            });
          }

          $("#Comments").on('click', ".bottomOptionBar a#doSubscribe", activateSubscribe);
          $("#Comments").on('click', ".bottomOptionBar a.togglePanelClose", function(){$(this).parent().fadeOut("fast"); return false;});
          $("#Comments").on('click', ".brandNewComment a.commentDeleteLink", deleteComment);
          $("#Comments").on('click', ".brandNewComment a.commentEditLink", editComment);
          $("#Comments").on('click', ".brandNewComment a.doneEditLink", editCommentSave);
          $("#Comments").on('click', ".brandNewComment a.cancelEditLink", editCommentCancel);
        })(jQuery);


        jQuery(document).ready(function($){
          $("#Comments").on('click', '#showMoreComments,#showAllComments', getMoreComments);
          $("#Comments #sortSelect").change(getMoreComments);
          getMoreComments();
          new Foundation.PostCommentComponent(componentId);
          var nc = Foundation.NotificationCenter.sharedNotificationCenter();
          nc.observe("comment:added", function (e) {
            var comment = e.data;
              getComment(comment.get("oid"), comment.get("commentLimit"));
            // clear rating
            if (jQuery(".commentFormRating").length!=0){
              jQuery(".commentFormRating input[name='reviewRating']").val("");
              jQuery(".commentFormRating .goldStarContainer").css("left", zeroPos+"px");
            }
          });
          var subscribeCheckBox = $("#Comments_commentSubscribe");
          subscribeCheckBox.prop("checked", getCookie("subscribeToThread") === "true" ? true : false);
          subscribeCheckBox.change(function (e) {
              var subscribeToThread = $(this).prop("checked");
              setCookie("subscribeToThread", subscribeToThread ? "true" : "false", 30);
          });
          var shareFacebookBox = $("#Comments_postCommentToFacebook");
          shareFacebookBox.prop("checked", getCookie("shareOnFacebook") === "true" ? true : false);
          shareFacebookBox.change(function (e) {
              var shareOnFacebook = $(this).prop("checked");
              setCookie("shareOnFacebook", shareOnFacebook ? "true" : "false", 30);
          });
          $("#Comments").on('click', 'a.likeLink', doLikeComment);
          $("#Comments").on('click', 'a.reportCommentLink', reportComment);
        });
      </script>

<script type="text/javascript">
<!--
  function showPopupCalendar (e) {
      var calid = this.id + ":dncal";
      var cal = $(calid).up();
      if (!cal) return;

      if (cal.visible()) {
          cal.blindUp({ duration: 0.3 });
      }
      else {
          dnCalendar.registry[calid].redraw();
          cal.blindDown({ duration: 0.3 });
      } 
  };

  function popupCalendarCallback (date, id) {

<span>

<div class="asset-content subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<style>#ndn-video-player-1.ndn_embedded .ndn_floatContainer { margin-top: 10px; margin-bottom: 20px; }</style>
<div class="ndn-container p402_hide">
<div class="ndn_embed" data-config-distributor-id="92172" data-config-height="9/16w" data-config-width="100%" id="ndn-video-player-1"></div>
<script type="text/javascript">var _ndnq = _ndnq || []; _ndnq.push(['embed']);</script>
</div>
<style>#ndn-video-player-2.ndn_embedded .ndn_floatContainer { margin-top: 10px; margin-bottom: 20px; }</style>
<div class="ndn-container p402_hide">
<div class="ndn_embed" data-config-distributor-id="92172" data-config-height="9/16w" data-config-width="100%" id="ndn-video-player-2"></div>
<script type="text/javascript">var _ndnq = _ndnq || []; _ndnq.push(['embed']);</script>
</div>
<p>The town of Konawa is urging residents to boil their water before using it.</p><p>Konawa officials discovered the presence of E. coli in the water supply after collecting three water samples earlier this week said Erin Hatfield, spokeswoman for the Oklahoma Department of Environmental Quality. An analysis showed that two of the three samples contained E. coli, and DEQ issued a boil order the same day.</p><p>Hatfield said Thursday that DEQ representatives will study Konawa’s water system and decide what steps should be taken to fix the problem.</p>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset, atf","fold":"above","include_domain":"cnhi\/adaeveningnews","size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/theadanews.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news"}' style="display:none;"></div>
<div data-refreshable="true" data-region="fixed-big-ad-top-asset">
</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><p>“Corrective actions may include providing adequate disinfection, completing needed operational improvements and correcting any construction deficiencies,” she said in an email to an Ada News reporter. “After the water system has completed all corrective actions, DEQ will require safe follow-up water samples to be collected. Once DEQ determines that the water system is providing a safe and stable water supply, DEQ will consider suspending the boil advisory.”</p><p>City Manager Tony Lowry did not immediately return a call seeking comment.</p><p>Konawa residents should bring their water to a full rolling boil, let it boil for one minute and then let it cool before using it for cooking, making ice, brushing their teeth or other tasks, according to the boil order. Boiling water kills bacteria and other organisms in the water.</p><p>People may also use bottled water instead of boiling it.</p><p>Fecal coliform and E. coli are both bacteria whose presence indicates that water may be contaminated with human or animal waste. Microbes in those wastes may cause short-term health problems, such as</p>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset, stf","fold":"span","include_domain":"cnhi\/adaeveningnews","size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/theadanews.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news"}' style="display:none;"></div>
<div data-refreshable="true" data-region="fixed-big-ad-middle-asset">
</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"><div class="tncms-block visible-xs" id="tncms-block-1169814">
<!-- Mobile Rectangle ATF 300x250 article -->
<div class="visible-xs visible-sm" id="mobileRectangle_atf" style="width:100%;text-align:center">
<script type="text/javascript">
AdBridg.cmd.push(function() { AdBridg.display('mobileRectangle_atf'); });
</script>
</div>
<div class="clear" style="padding-bottom:10px"></div>
</div></div><p>diarrhea, cramps, nausea or headaches.</p><p>The microbes may create a special health risk for young children, elderly people and those with severely compromised immune systems.</p><p>Bacterial contamination may occur when increased run-off enters a source of drinking water, such as during heavy rains. Contamination may also occur due to a break in the water distribution system or a failure in the water treatment process.</p><p>In light of the problem, town officials asked the owner of the Konawa Sonic drive-in restaurant to shut off its water, said Jason Acock, Sonic’s manager of corporate communications. He added that  other Konawa businesses are also closed.</p><p>“The franchisee who owns and operates the drive-in closed immediately and will reopen only when given approval by local authorities,” Acock said in a written statement. “Sonic and its franchisees pride ourselves on providing customers with safe food and friendly service. We hope the city finds a quick resolution to this issue.”</p>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-bottom-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-bottom-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-bottom-asset, btf","fold":"below","include_domain":"cnhi\/adaeveningnews","size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/theadanews.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news"}' style="display:none;"></div>

Some Burlington County Lakes Closed After Campers, Staffers Fall Ill

August 6, 2015 9:34 PM By Cleve Bryan

By Cleve Bryan

MEDFORD, N.J., (CBS) — Some lakes in Burlington County, New Jersey are closed after campers and staffers came down with flu-like symptoms.

Testing on the water is now being performed by the County Department of Health.

As CBS 3 Eyewitness News New Jersey Reporter Cleve Bryan reports, the lakes in Medford are used by three camps.

Campers told to stay out of the water at the YMCA’s Camp Ockanickon in Medford.

“Got a notice last night, got a text last night that they had to cancel family night last night because of the bacteria in the water,” said a grandparent of a camper.

Camp officials say that about a half a dozen children and adults complained of feeling sick to their stomachs starting late last weekend. Not sure of the cause, they aren’t letting anyone in the lakes on property and notified the Burlington County Health Department.

“Wondering what she could have potentially contracted in the water if they’re concerned about something with the lake and what I should be looking for as far as her being ill or anything,” said a parent of a camper.

This time of year the most common health concern for lake swimming is fecal caliform, bacteria that often comes from goose and other animal droppings.

“Fecal caliform is a big concern because that can enter the body, especially when you drink the water and as a child you will accidently drink the water, it’s almost a given, and you will ingest that and that could potentially lead to diarrhea,” said Camden County Health Liaison Carmen Rodriguez.

Camp officials say they can’t be certain that the stomach illnesses were caused by bacteria in the lakes, but they say they won’t reopen the waterfront activities until they get clean test results with the water quality.

“Some places don’t test the water, they test the water here and they keep track of it so they’re on top of it,” said a parent of a camper.

Parents CBS 3 Eyewitness News met with say they aren’t overly concerned, but are anxious to hear the results of the water tests.
